awd_titl_txt: Towards Integrated Noise Thermometry and Its Applications to Embedded Temperature measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop an integrated solution to low-cost Johnson noise thermometers (JNT) with significantly faster speed than currently available, and to demonstrate its practical application to on-chip temperature measurement. The approach is to follow the same Nyquist noise principle that enabled other primary JNTs, but to focus on the most widely used industrial temperature range over which sensitivity and bandwidth requirements are drastically relaxed, and to reduce measurement time from hours to milliseconds for practical use by integrating several innovative circuit design and digital signal processing techniques.

The primary intellectual merit of the research is in developing the first practical integrated solution to JNTs. A further intellectual merit is in providing an accurate and inherently linear temperature sensor and/or sensor reference for embedded applications. Other intellectual merits include novel circuit design techniques for eliminating speed bottlenecks in primary JNTs, and sampling and post-processing techniques for significantly reducing measurement errors. Finally, this research introduces a new on-chip multi-temperature self-calibration scheme for other embedded temperature sensors.

An immediate broader impact of the research is the wide applicability of the integrated thermometer in science, industry and everyday uses. The new technology also has a high probability of being adopted by industry and creating a direct economic impact. Targeted approaches are planned to facilitate recruiting and training of female and minority students.  Several noise and temperature measurement techniques and laboratory experiments will be incorporated into undergraduate courses. Finally, nontraditional dissemination activities will further broaden the project's impact.

por.por_cntn:
Johnson noise is a fundamental thermal dynamics behavior and its measurement can be used as a primary indicator of temperature. It has excellent linear relationship over an extremely wide temperature range. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and foreign countries' counterparts have spent major efforts and developed various solutions of Johnson noise thermometers (JNTs). But these solutions have complicated, expensive, and slow.

The main technical outcome of this project is the first investigation, development, and demonstration of a simple, low-cost, and fast operating JNT that can be integrated in standard CMOS technologies. Challenges in dramatically miniaturizing the large NIST JNT systems are investigated. The error sources resulting from severe limitations in on-chip area and power resources are identified. New circuit design techniques are developed to overcome these challenges, compensate for the error sources, and to take advantages of the significantly reduced on-chip parasitics and the orders of magnitude higher sampling speed. With these, a small integrated JNT circuit was designed in a standard CMOS technology. The JNT was embedded in another integrated circuit chip fabricated in a commercial process. A PCB was designed and fabricated for testing the JNT performance. Measurement results demonstrated the feasibility of the integrated JNT concept, its inherent linearity, and a very promising performance of 1.1oC accuracy.

A second technical outcome was the development and demonstration of ultra-small temperature sensors that could be embedded in many different locations inside a single integrated circuit chip. One such sensor was based on the temperature dependence of MOS transistor’s threshold voltage. The core area of the sensor is smaller than a fraction of a pad. After that, a direct temperature to digital converter was developed that requires no analog signal processing, no voltage reference, and no ADC, but provides digital output of temperature. These tiny temperature sensors have offsets that are process corner dependent and these offset can be calibrated out by the JNT. Multiple chips were designed and tested. Measurement results demonstrated the concepts and performance.

A third outcome was in technology transfer. During the project, close engagement with semiconductor companies was maintained. All graduate students on the project had one or more intern or co-op opportunities. The proposed technologies for tiny temperature sensor design have been transferred to Biotronik Micro Systems Engineering Inc., Texas Instruments, and TSMC.

A fourth outcome of the project was in the recruiting, training, and mentoring of a diverse workforce in the STEM area. Three PhD students participated in and partially supported by the project. Two of them are females, and female PhDs in the integrated circuit design area are extremely under-represented. Tina Wang worked on designing tiny, threshold voltage based temperature sensors, and she is currently working at TSMC. Monica Zhao worked on designing direct temperature to digital converters and she is currently working at Broadcom. A third student, Xu Zhang, worked various JNT issues and integrated JNT design, and he is currently working at Qualcomm. In addition to these three PhD students, six undergraduate students were also involved at various stages of the project, either for their undergraduate research or for their senior design project.

A final outcome of the project was its impact on two existing courses in the VLSI area. For EE 435, an undergraduate course on introduction to analog and mixed-signal integrated circuit design, one lecture module was created on Johnson noise analysis and one laboratory was introduced on simulation Johnson noise and its propagation in a circuit. For EE 590H, an advanced topics course in the integrated circuit design area, research findings from the project were presented to the class, and students were instructed to recreated two of the proposed temperature sensor designs.
